title: 104_hr4016
content: The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include State Grants for Drug and Violence Prevention Programs. The Secretary reserves funds for grants to Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, programs for Indian youth, national impact evaluation, and programs for Native Hawaiians. State allotments are also specified. The Secretary reserves funds for grants to specific territories, programs for Indian youth, national impact evaluation, and programs for Native Hawaiians. State allotments are allocated based on school-aged population and previous funding received under part A of title I. The Secretary may reallot funds to a State if they cannot be used within two years, based on the school-aged population and previous funding received under part A of title I. The Secretary has the authority to reallot funds to States if they cannot be utilized within two years. States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico are included in the definition of 'State', while 'local educational agency' encompasses educational service agencies and their consortia. "SEC. 4112. STATE APPLICATIONS." To receive funding under section 4111, the State's chief executive officer must submit an application to the Secretary. The application must outline how funds will be coordinated with other programs, provide the State's needs assessment for drug and violence prevention programs, and assure cooperation with the Secretary for national impact assessments. The State's application for drug and violence prevention funding must include data on drug use and violence, cooperate with the Secretary for national impact evaluations, and meet any additional requirements. The Secretary will use a peer review process to review State applications. "SEC. 4113. STATE PROGRAMS." The chief executive officer of a State must use allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs. Administrative costs are limited to 5% of the total amount received. Grants are meant for prevention and education programs on the dangers of illegal drug use and underage drinking. The funds allocated for prevention and education programs must be used solely for anti-drug messaging. Any diversion of funds for other purposes will result in penalties, including forfeiture and reimbursement. The funds allocated for prevention and education programs must be used solely for anti-drug messaging. Violations, including penalties like forfeiture and reimbursement, apply to misapplication of funds. Grants awarded under this program are subject to peer review, and the chief executive officer of a State can directly carry out activities or use grants. Law enforcement education partnerships involve awarding grants to agencies in consortium with educational entities. The chief executive officer can use funds for grants to law enforcement agencies in partnership with educational or community-based agencies for drug abuse and violence prevention activities, including programs like Drug Abuse Resistance Education and Legal Lives. The prevention activities include teaching students to recognize and resist pressures to use substances, classroom instruction in the law, partnerships between law enforcement and child guidance professionals, and before- and after-school activities. "SEC. 4114. EVALUATION AND REPORTING." The Secretary conducts a biennial evaluation of national impact of programs to combat school violence, collecting data on violence frequency and seriousness in elementary and secondary schools. The National Center for Education Statistics collects data on violence in elementary and secondary schools, with a report due to Congress by January 1, 2000. States must submit reports on implementation every third year to the Secretary. The chief executive officer of the State must submit a report to the Secretary every third year on the implementation and outcomes of State programs under section 4113, including data on drug use and violence by youth in schools and communities. The report must be in a specified form, based on ongoing evaluation activities, and made available to the public. The Secretary will provide grants to organizations serving Native Hawaiians recognized by the Governor of Hawaii to administer programs for their benefit. Native Hawaiian is defined as individuals with ancestors native to Hawaii before 1778.
